discussion.content: Most voted is for answer B and instead answer D is selected. Please fix

Selected Answer: B
Given that developer mode and installs from unknown sources are enabled, there is a strong possibility that malicious applications could have been installed on the smartphone without the user’s knowledge. Malicious apps can run in the background, consuming significant data by connecting to the internet, sending information, or downloading additional content. Checking for these apps is crucial to resolving the high data usage issue

Selected Answer: B
You need to check if malicious apps were installed since unknown sources is enabled, clearly something is using the data since it's not the user.

comments.content: Permissions of what? It's a phone. You need to check if malicious apps were installed since unknown sources is enabled, clearly something is using the data since it's not the user.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Need to check permissions first

questions.question_text: A customer reports high data usage on a smartphone that reaches its monthly data limit within the first week of each billing cycle. The customer uses the phone primarily for calls and SMS messages with minimal content streaming. A technician troubleshoots the phone and notices that both developer mode and installs from unknown sources are enabled. Which of the following should the technician check next?

choices.A: Shut down the infected computer and swap it with another computer.
choices.C: Proceed with initiating a full scan and removal of the viruses using the presented interface.
choices.B: Investigate what the interface is and what triggered it to pop up.
choices.D: Call the phone number displayed in the interface of the antivirus removal tool.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The tech doesn't recognize the interface. So don't use it.

comments.content: More likely the original answer is wrong as the pdf they came from held that answer. That is what makes examtopics stand out; intelligent discussion around the question.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Some of these questions are answered wrong on purpose so that Exam topics could avoid copyright issues with these tests. But its also good that we have discussion boxes to mitigate these kinds of things, so no, if it quacks like a duck and walks like a duck, then its probably a virus and you shouldn't click on it. The answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
Mnemonic for remembering steps of malware removal:
Very Quiet Dogs Really Snore Every Evening
Verify (that it really is malware)
Quarantine (unplug network cable/wifi, find any storage or devices attached and remove from areas where it could be used)
Disable (system restore)
Remediate (Do the actual removal of malware)
Enable (enable system restore again
Educate (educate the end user with 1 on 1 or general message, boards, posters etc.)
---------------------
Since the technician has not yet verified its malware, she/he needs to check what triggered it and what it looks like to see if any of the following steps are necessary.

Selected Answer: A
Why are more people not saying A? The system has not yet been quarantined? That's always the first step, right? It's pretty obvious this is a Virus of some kind.
Would "A" be likened to quarantining the affected system?

Selected Answer: B
cateegorically B, why would you use an interface you dont recognize?

Selected Answer: B
It's important for the technician to understand the nature of the interface and what triggered it to appear.

Selected Answer: B
Obvious answer. It’s a fake anti-virus software.
Seems like C is the answers every indian call center scammer wants.

Selected Answer: B
makes the most sense... why would you use an interface you dont recognize? it can be a pop up ad virus

Selected Answer: B
The technician must first determine whether it is legitimate or a potential scam. Therefore, he needs to (B) Investigate what the interface is and what triggered it to pop up.

Selected Answer: B
If the interface is unfamiliar or suspicious, definitely don't use it. B is the only answer that presents a troubleshooting step and doesn't fall for the malware.
C is literally the worst possible answer. Use the scammers own software to remove the virus! Wont end well. B is correct

Selected Answer: B
No doubt about this one: B. Investigate what the interface is and what triggered it to pop up.
The answer is B

Step 1 - Identify malware symptoms, Step 2 - Quarantine infected systems, Step 3 - Disable System Restore, Step 4 - Remediate infected systems, Step 5 - Schedule scans and run updates, Step 6 - Enable System Restore and create restore point, Step 7 - Educate user,

So I think the answer is B identify the symptom

Selected Answer: B
B makes more sense

Selected Answer: B
tech is rookie

Selected Answer: A
C makes no sense why would you use an unrecognized interface to perform a virus scan?

comments.content: I agree, but I wouldn't go with A as this does not solve the issue.

questions.question_text: A user reports that antivirus software indicates a computer is infected with viruses. The user thinks this happened while browsing the internet. The technician does not recognize the interface with which the antivirus message is presented. Which of the following is the NEXT step the technician should take?

discussion.content:
D. Sandbox testing
Sandbox testing involves testing new software in a controlled environment, isolated from the production environment. By testing the new software in a sandbox, the developer could have identified any potential conflicts or issues with the file server before deploying it to the production environment. This would have prevented the disruption of file server access for all users.

Google Gemini

questions.question_text: A developer installed a new software package that has stopped all file server access. Which of the following change management practices should have been followed?

A user takes a work-issued laptop home for the first time. When the user attempts to browse any website on the home internet, the user receives the following error:

"This site cannot be reached."

A technician from work confirms that the static IP that was set up on the machine was changed back to DHCP. Which of the following needs to be corrected?

discussion.content:
C. DNS
DNS (Domain Name System) is responsible for translating domain names (like [invalid URL removed]) into IP addresses that computers can understand. If the DNS settings on the laptop are incorrect or not configured, the device won't be able to resolve domain names and access websites.

Since the laptop's IP address changed to DHCP, it likely lost its previous DNS configuration. The technician needs to ensure that the laptop is configured to use the correct DNS servers, either manually or through DHCP.

Google Gemini

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of malware is designed to enable administrative access to a computer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Rootkit
Here's why:

 Rootkit: A rootkit is a type of malware specifically designed to give an attacker administrative or "root" access to a computer or network. It can hide its presence and allow the attacker to control the system without the user’s knowledge.
